document.docTitle: Identification and characterization of (+)-α-bisabolol and 7-epi-silphiperfol- 5-ene synthases from Artemisia abrotanum

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Identification and characterization of (+)-α-bisabolol and 7-epi-silphiperfol- 5-ene synthases from Artemisia abrotanum

paragraph.docTitle:
Identification and characterization of (+)-α- bisabolol and 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene synthases from
Artemisia abrotanum

subSection.paragraph:
Hideyuki Suzuki d , Hikaru Seki
a,c,
∗
, Toshiya Muranaka a,c

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Department of Biotechnology, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka University 2-1 Yamadaoka, Suita, Osaka , 565-0871, Japan

paragraph.emphasis: KNC Laboratories Co., Ltd., 3-2-34 Takatsukadai , Nishi-ku , Kobe , Hyogo , 651-2271, Japan
Kihara Institute for Biological Research , Yokohama City University 641-12 Maioka-cho , Totsuka-ku , Yokohama , Kanagawa , 244-0813, Japan
Department of Applied Genomics , Kazusa DNA Research Institute , 2-6-7 Kazusa-kamatari , Kisarazu , Chiba , 292-0818, Japan

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

Artemisia abrotanum
L . Asteraceae
Sesquiterpenoid profiling Sesquiterpene synthase Triquinane-type sesquiterpenoid (+)-α- Bisabolol synthase 7- Epi -Silphiperfol-5-ene synthase AabrBOS
AabrSPS
A B S T R A C T

Triquinane is a type of sesquiterpenoid with a unique structure that contains a fused tricyclopentane ring and exhibits a wide range of bioactivities. Like other sesquiterpenoids, the first committed step in triquinane-type sesquiterpenoid biosynthesis is the cyclization of farnesyl pyrophosphate (FPP), a common precursor of all sesquiterpenoids, catalyzed by sesquiterpene synthase.
Artemisia abrotanum
L . ( Asteraceae ), a common plant used in the culinary and cosmetics industries, has been reported to accumulate high levels of triquinane silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A . This compound is potentially biosynthesized from the cyclization of FPP into 7- epi - silphiperfol-5-ene followed by a multi-step oxidation to silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A . In this study, we aimed to identify the sesquiterpene synthase responsible for the synthesis of 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene. We performed RNA sequencing of
A . abrotanum
leaves and gene candidates were mined by homology searches using the triquinane α- isocomene synthase of chamomile (MrTPS2) as query. After gene cloning, we obtained five variants of putative sesquiterpene synthase showing greater than 85% amino acid identity to MrTPS2 and greater than 95% amino acid identity to each other. Heterologous expression of these variants in a FPP-high-producing yeast strain revealed the first four variants to be (+)-α- bisabolol synthases (AabrBOS1–4). However, the fifth candidate cyclized FPP into 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene and can therefore be defined as a 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene synthase (AabrSPS). These findings revealed the first committed enzyme involved in silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A and (+)-αbisabolol biosyntheses in
A . abrotanum
. Furthermore, the results of this study will be useful for enhancing the production of these compounds for further applications.
https://doi.org/ 10.1016/j.phytochem.2019.05.010

Received 11 April 2019 ; Received in revised form 30 April 2019 ; Accepted 10 May 2019 isocomene, a triquinane-type sesquiterpenoid, was recently identified in the chamomile plant (
Matricaria recutita
L .) (MrTPS2; Fig. 1 ; Irmisch et al., 2012 ). This finding provided new insight into the possibility of producing this compound via a synthetic biology approach and initiated the search for sesquiterpene synthases responsible for the synthesis of other triquinanes.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. Proposed biosynthetic pathways of silphiperfol-5-en- 3-one A and (+)-α- bisabolol in
A . abrotanum
. The enzymes responsible for each step are indicated with arrows. The full names of the enzymes are given in the text. Determined biosynthetic pathways in this study are highlighted in bold. The α- bisabolol oxide A, detected by Radulovi ć et al. (2009) and the previously reported sesquiterpene synthase synthesizing triquinane α- isocomene (MrTPS2; Irmisch et al., 2012 ) are also included. Dot arrows indicate a multi-step conversion.

subSection.paragraph:
Our research group has been interested in the chemical diversity of sesquiterpenoids and their biosynthesis in
Artemisia spp.
( Asteraceae ), and previously published our studies on the discovery of three sesquiterpene synthases: koidzumiol synthase from
A . absinthium
L . (AabKOS), (+)-α- bisabolol synthases from
A . kurramensis Qazilb.
and
A . maritima
L . (AkBOS and AmBOS), and 4-amorphen-11-ol synthase from
A . maritima (AmAOS)
( Muangphrom et al., 2016 , 2018 ). Among the compounds that have been isolated from more than 400
Artemisia spp.
( The Plant List, 2013 ), the antimalarial artemisinin, from
Artemisia annua
L ., is the most renowned bioactive sesquiterpene, while other
Artemisia species
also accumulate a wide variety of sesquiterpenoids with interesting pharmaceutical and biomedical properties. In particular,
A . abrotanum
L . ( Asteraceae ), a common plant used in the culinary and cosmetic industries and for the treatment of various disorders and diseases of the upper respiratory tract ( Brodin et al., 2007 ; Remberg et al., 2004 ), accumulates high levels of silphiperfol-5-en-3- one A , a triquinane-type sesquiterpenoid ( Obistioiu et al., 2014 ; Radulovi ć et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2018 ). Silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A and its derivatives are known for their odoriferous properties which can be developed and used as insect repellents, preservatives, and perfumes ( Weyerstahl and Brendel, 1992 ). Silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A can be synthesized from the cyclization of FPP into 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene followed by a multi-step oxidation, as shown in Fig. 1 . However, little is known about its biosynthesis, including the enzymes involved in the pathway. We therefore started to investigate possible enzymes responsible for the biosynthesis of silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A in
A . abrotanum
. In this study, we performed transcriptome sequencing of
A . abrotanum
leaves and mined a candidate gene potentially encoding 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene synthase based on amino acid sequence similarity to MrTPS2. After gene cloning and in vivo enzymatic functional analysis, we discovered a sesquiterpene synthase synthesizing 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene. Thus, we named this enzyme 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene synthase (AabrSPS). In addition, we also discovered four variants of (+)-α- bisabolol synthase (AabrBOS1–4) from
A . abrotanum
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Sesquiterpenoid profiles of two different strains of
A . abrotanum
were analyzed. GC-MS analyses of n- hexane extracts of the aerial parts of
A . abrotanum
revealed 15 sesquiterpenoids, tentatively identified based on comparisons of retention indices and mass spectra with those of authentic compounds and reference data ( Fig. S1 and Table 1 ; Adams, 2007 ). β- Caryophyllene, germacrene D, bicyclogermacrene, and silphiperfolane-type sesquiterpenoids have been previously identified in
A . abrotanum
( Obistioiu et al., 2014 ; Radulovi ć et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2018 ), whereas detection of β- and δ- elemenes, α- and βcopaenes, and α- humulene in this study is the first report of these compounds in
A . abrotanum
. Among all detected compounds, tricyclic silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A occupied 60% of the total sesquiterpenoid content of the extract. This finding strongly supported that the as yet unidentified gene encoding silphiperfolene synthase is highly expressed in the
A . abrotanum
used in this study.

subSection.paragraph:
To identify genes involved in the biosynthesis of silphiperfol-5-en-3- one A and related compounds in
A . abrotanum
, total RNA extracted from
A . abrotanum
leaves was sequenced using the Illumina HiSeq 2000 platform. We obtained 19,919,288 reads in total and assembled these into 39,743 contigs ( Table 2 ). Candidate tricyclic sesquiterpene synthases were then mined by a tblastn search against 39,743 contigs using the amino acid sequence of the only previously identified plant-derived tricyclic sesquiterpene synthase, MrTPS2 ( Irmisch et al., 2012 ) as a query. We found a contig containing a partial open reading frame (ORF) of a putative tricyclic sesquiterpene synthase. After 5′ and 3′ RACE-PCR and subsequent RT-PCR amplification, complete ORFs of five variants of putative tricyclic sesquiterpene synthase were obtained. These are referred to as AabrBOS1–4 and AabrSPS in accordance with their enzymatic activities following functional analyses. The deduced amino acid sequences of AabrBOS1–4 and AabrSPS, each composed of 546 amino acids, showed high amino acid identities of greater than 85% to MrTPS2 (Supplementary Table S1 ) and contained all conserved motifs important for the initiation of substrate ionization and complexation in terpene synthases; i.e ., R(R,P)(X) 8 W, RXR, DDXXD, and NSE/DTE motifs ( Figs. 2 and S2 ; Brock and Dickschat, 2013 ; Christianson, 2006 , 2017 ; Degenhardt et al., 2009 ; Ee et al., 2014 ; He et al., 2018 ; Tholl et al., 2005 ). Although their DDXXD and NSE/DTE motifs are identical, AabrBOS1 and AabrBOS4 showed one amino acid difference at the R (R,P)(X) 8 W and RXR motifs. Phylogenetic analysis showed that AabrBOS1–4 and AabrSPS are located in the same clade as MrTPS2 and in the same node as
A . annua
β- caryophyllene synthase (AaQHS1), which catalyzes 1,11- and 2,10-cyclizations, and
A . annua
8- epi -cedrol synthase (AaECS1), which catalyzes a three-step cyclization reaction ( Fig. 3 ; Cai et al., 2002 ; Hua and Matsuda, 1999 ). However, AabrBOS1–4 grouped together while AabrSPS was distinctly separate, despite having an amino acid identity of more than 95% to the others ( Fig. 3 and Supplementary Table S1 ). This result suggests that the catalytic activity of AabrSPS may differ from that of AabrBOS1–4.

Table 1 The sesquiterpenoid profile of
A. abrotanum
.

strain 1 which was purchased from a local herb store in Japan.

A. abrotanum

Table 2 Summary of the RNA-Seq analysis of
A. abrotanum
.

tr.th: Number of total reads used in the assembly

heading.emphasis: 2.3. In vivo enzymatic assay of putative sesquiterpene synthases

subSection.paragraph:
For functional identification, AabrBOS1–4 and AabrSPS were individually expressed in the FPP-high-producing
Saccharomyces cerevisiae
strain EPY300 ( Ro et al., 2006 , 2008 ). After culturing, in vivo metabolites were extracted and analyzed by GC-MS. As shown in Fig. 4A and B , AabrBOS1–4 each yielded the same reaction product, compound 1 [retention time (RT) = 12.13 min] as a major product, while AabrSPS produced compound 2 (RT = 8.04 min) as a major product. Note that compound 2 differed from compound
1 in
both RT and mass fragmentation pattern. Neither compound was detected from the yeast strain that had been transformed with the empty control vector. The estimated yield of each product, relative to the concentration of the internal standard n- tetradecane, with AabrBOS1–4 and AabrSPS was 355, 318, 507, 326, and 68 mg /l, respectively. Tyrosol, 2,4-di- tert -butyl phenol, nerolidol, and farnesol are endogenously produced in
S . cerevisiae
( Jewison et al., 2012 ; Ramirez-Gaona et al., 2017 ). The mass spectra of these endogenous compounds are shown in Fig. S3.

To determine its structure, compound 1 was purified from AabrBOS1 -transformed yeast cultures by column chromatography and analyzed by NMR spectroscopy. Correlations observed in 2D-NMR spectra ( Figs. S4–S 14 and Supplementary Table S2 ) revealed the structure of this compound to be α- bisabolol. Comparisons with 1 H and 13 C-NMR spectroscopic data of standard (-)-α- bisabolol (Figs. S15 and S16 and Supplementary Table S3) and reported data of (-)- epi -α- bisabolol ( Chen et al., 1993 ) further confirmed that compound 1 was not epi -α- bisabolol. Specific rotation analysis showed that the [α] D 12 of this compound was +59.5 ( c 0.26, MeOH), which was sufficiently close to the reported value of (+)-α- bisabolol of [α] D 20 +57.04 (MeOH) ( Günther et al., 1993 ). Thus, compound 1 was identified as (+)-α- bisabolol ( Fig. 4C ), indicating that AabrBOS1–4 are (+)-α- bisabolol synthases.

We previously identified (+)-α- bisabolol synthases from
A . kurramensis
and
A . maritima
(AkBOS and AmBOS; Muangphrom et al., 2016 ). Although AabrBOS1–4 identified in this study are in a different group than AkBOS and AmBOS, all of them share the same node separate from other BOSs producing different stereoisomers of α- bisabolol ( Fig. 3 ). This result indicates that while enzymes from the same plant species may group together, enzyme function across species is convergent.

Four variants of (+)-α- bisabolol synthase were identified in
A . abrotanum
. However, (+)-α- bisabolol and its related compounds were not detected in the crude n- hexane extracts of this plant ( Fig. S1 and Table 1 ). Although this result is consistent with those of Obistioiu et al. (2014) , Radulovi ć et al. (2009) detected certain (+)-α- bisabolol derivatives; i.e ., α- bisabolol oxide A and its acetate form, in this plant. This difference suggests that most of the (+)-α- bisabolol produced by
A . abrotanum
may be converted to its derivatives ( Fig. 1 ) and the remaining quantity of (+)-α- bisabolol was too low to be detected in the current study. Also note that the sesquiterpenoid profile of the same plant species can vary depending on the plant cultivar and the environmental conditions during growth.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Amino acid sequence alignment of AabrBOS1–4, AabrSPS, and MrTPS2. Typical motifs of sesquiterpene synthases are underlined: R(R,P)(X) 8 W, pink; RXR, blue; DDXXD, red; and NSE/DTE, green. Putative catalytic residues located within 12 Å of the active site are indicated by yellow boxes. Black shading indicates identical amino acid residues. Asterisks indicate putative residues involved in the stabilization of carbocation intermediates. Black triangles indicate putative catalytic residues involved in 1,10-cyclization. The green triangle indicates the putative catalytic residue involved in 1,6-cyclization. Blue triangles indicate the residues potentially involved in deprotonation and reprotonation during the cyclization reaction of FPP. Pink shading indicates residues conserved in AabrBOS1–4 that differ in AabrSPS and MrTPS2. Yellow shading indicates residues conserved in AabrSPS and MrTPS2 that differ in AabrBOS1–4. GenBank accession numbers of the aligned enzymes are provided in Supplementary Table S1. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph: To determine its structure, compound 2 was purified from AabrSPS - transformed yeast cultures by column chromatography and analyzed by NMR spectroscopy. As shown in Figs. S17–S27 and Supplementary Table S4, correlations observed in COSY and HMBC NMR spectra revealed the structure of this compound to be silphiperfol-5-ene. Correlations between H-1, H-14, and H- 15 in the NOESY spectrum of 2 determined the relative configurations at C-1, C-14, and C-15 to be S* , R* , and R* , respectively. Likewise, correlations between H-11a, H-11b, and H-12 revealed the relative configurations at C-4 and C-8 to be S* and R* , respectively. This interpretation matches those of previously reported NMR spectroscopic data of 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene ( Bohlmann and Jakupovic, 1980 ; Wender and Singh, 1985 ; Weyerstahl et al., 1991 ). Thus, compound 2 was identified as 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene ( Fig. 4C ), indicating that AabrSPS is a 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene synthase.

Triquinane-type sesquiterpenes have attracted a great deal of attention due to their unique tricyclopentane ring structure featuring several stereogenic centers. So far, MrTPS2 from chamomile is the only reported plant sesquiterpene synthase that catalyzes the cyclization of FPP into triquinane-type α- isocomene ( Irmisch et al., 2012 ) via 1,11- and 2,10-ring closures that generate the caryophyllenyl cation, followed by a multi-step carbocationic cyclization/rearrangement ( Fig. 5 ; Bohlmann and Jakupovic, 1980 ; Hong et al., 2013 ; Menut et al., 1997 ; Tantillo, 2017 ). In this study, we discovered AabrSPS the sesquiterpene synthase responsible for the production of triquinane 7-
epi-
silphiperfol-5-ene, an important precursor of silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A in
A . abrotanum
( Figs. 1 , 4 , and S1 and Table 1 ; Obistioiu et al., 2014 ; Radulovi ć et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2018 ). The cyclization mechanism of FPP to 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene has been previously proposed ( Bohlmann and Jakupovic, 1980 ; Coates et al., 1998 ; Menut et al., 1997 ). Thus, we incorporated these into our previous summary of the biosynthetic mechanism of sesquiterpenoids catalyzed by the characterized sesquiterpene synthases from
Artemisia spp.
in Muangphrom et al. (2018) , as shown in Fig. 5 .

Silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A is a major triquinane sesquiterpenoid found in
A . abrotanum
. In an attempt to identify the sesquiterpene synthase responsible for the biosynthesis of silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A , we performed transcriptome sequencing of
A . abrotanum
leaves and mined the candidates using the previously identified triquinane sesquiterpene synthase MrTPS2 as query. After gene cloning, we obtained five variants of putative sesquiterpene synthase. An in vivo enzymatic assay against FPP in yeast revealed four of the variants, namely AabrBOS1–4, to be specific (+)-α- bisabolol synthases. This is the first report of this enzyme in
A . abrotanum
. The last variant, namely AabrSPS, was identified as a 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene synthase synthesizing 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene, the biosynthetic precursor of silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A . This enzyme is the first known committed enzyme in silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A biosynthesis in
A . abrotanum
. Its discovery and characterization will significantly simplify the production of triquinane-type sesquiterpenoids for further studies.

heading.emphasis: 4.1. Plant materials, yeast strain and chemicals

subSection.paragraph:
Two different strains of
Artemisia abrotanum
L . ( Asteraceae ) were obtained. Strain 1 was purchased from a local herb store, Maypop ( Fukuoka , Japan ). Strain 2 was kindly provided by the Ocean Exposition Commemorative Park Management Foundation ( Okinawa , Japan ). The plants were cultivated in Jiffymix (Sakata Seed Corporation, Yokohama, Japan ) and Sanyaso-no-tsuchi (Ohmiya Green Service, Saitama , Japan ) under natural light and environmental conditions at the Kihara Institute for Biological Research (35̊24′ N, 139̊33 E), located in Yokohama, Japan , and harvested in May 2008 with an average monthly temperature of 18.0 ̊ C and relative humidity of 70%. The collected young leaves of
A . abrotanum
strain 1 were frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80 ̊ C until used for total RNA extraction.

The yeast
Saccharomyces cerevisiae EPY
300 strain of genotype
MAT αα his3
Δ 1 leu2 Δ 0 lys2 Δ 0 ura3 Δ 0 P GAL1-tHMGR P GAL1-upc2-1 erg9 : PMET3-ERG9 P GAL1-tHMGR P GAL1-ERG20 was previously developed to increase FPP production ( Ro et al., 2006 , 2008 ).

n -Tetradecane and (-)-α- bisabolol were purchased from SigmaAldrich (St. Louis, MO, USA ). Silica gel 100N (spherical, neutral, particle size 100–230 μm) was purchased from Kanto Chemical Industry ( Tokyo , Japan ). The 10% AgNO 3 impregnated silica gel was purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries ( Osaka , Japan ). Alkane standard mixture ( C 10– C 20) was purchased from GL-Sciences ( Tokyo , Japan ). Other chemicals and solvents were purchased from Kishida Chemical Co., Ltd. ( Osaka , Japan ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3. Phylogenetic relationships among
Artemisia spp.
sesquiterpene synthases and characterized bisabolol synthases. The rooted neighbor-joining tree was generated based on the amino acid sequences of sesquiterpene synthases identified in
Artemisia species
and characterized plant bisabolol synthases using CLUSTALW and MEGA7 software. The numbers indicate the bootstrap value (%) obtained from 10,000 replications. Enzymes characterized in this study are highlighted in bold. GenBank accession numbers and the full names of each enzyme are provided in Supplementary Table S1. The first cyclization mechanism catalyzed by each enzyme is indicated in square brackets. Functions of all enzymes were previously reported in AaADS: Bouwmeester et al. (1999) , Chang et al. (2000) , Mercke et al. (2000) ; AaBOS: Li et al. (2013) ; AaECS1: Hua and Matsuda (1999) ; AaFS: Picaud et al. (2005) ; AaGAS: Bertea et al. (2006) ; AaQHS1: Cai et al. (2002) ; AabKOS1, AkBOS, AmBOS: Muangphrom et al. (2016) ; AmAOS: Muangphrom et al. (2018) ; EeBOS: Albertti et al. (2018) ; MrBOS: Son et al. (2014) ; MrTPS2: Irmisch et al. (2012) ; PdBOS: Attia et al. (2012) ; SsBOS: Jones et al. (2011) .

heading.emphasis: 4.2. Sesquiterpenoid profiling of A. abrotanum L

subSection.paragraph:
The aerial parts of
A . abrotanum
L. ( 320 mg ) were extracted three times with n -hexane. After drying over anhydrous Na 2 SO 4 , the extracts were concentrated under reduced pressure and a flow of nitrogen gas before being re-dissolved in 1 ml n- hexane for GC-MS analysis as described in 4.7. Sesquiterpenoids were identified from comparisons of GC retention indices and mass spectra with those of authentic compounds and reference data ( Adams, 2007 ). n -Tetradecane was used for the quantification of each detected sesquiterpenoid and alkane standard mixture (C10–C20) was used to determine retention indices.

Total RNA was extracted from frozen leaves using PureLink Plant RNA Reagent (ThermoFisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA ), treated with recombinant DNaseI (RNase-free) (Takara Bio, Shiga , Japan ), and purified using the RNeasy Plant Mini Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany ) following the RNA clean-up protocol.

First-strand cDNA was synthesized from 1 μg total RNA prepared from
A . abrotanum
leaves using the SMARTer RACE cDNA Amplification Kit (Clontech/TaKaRa Bio) according to the manufacturer's instructions. To obtain the missing 5′ and 3′ end sequences of a contig (1,303 bp) containing the partial ORF of a putative tricyclic sesquiterpene synthase, 5′-RACE PCR using primers 1 (first) and 2 (nested), and 3′-RACE PCR using primers 3 (first) and 4 (nested) were performed. Using sequence information obtained by RACE-PCR, primers 5 and 6 were designed to amplify a complete ORF. The complete ORFs of AabrBOS s and AabrSPS were amplified using PrimeSTAR Max DNA Polymerase (Takara Bio) and the amplified product was cloned into a pENTR/D-TOPO (ThermoFisher Scientific) and sequenced. The sequences of all primers used in this study are listed in Supplementary Table S5. The nucleotide sequences isolated in this study have been submitted to DDBJ under the accession numbers LC469617 (AabrBOS1), LC469618 (AabrBOS2), LC469619 (AabrBOS3), LC469620 (AabrBOS4), and LC469621 (AabrSPS), respectively.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 4. In vivo
enzymatic assay of AabrBOS1–4 and AabrSPS. ( A ) The total ion chromatogram displays the extracts of yeast transformed with the empty vector (negative control), AabrBOS1 , AabrBOS2 , AabrBOS3 , AabrBOS4 , and AabrSPS . ( B ) Mass spectra and ( C ) chemical structures of the detected (+)-α- bisabolol ( 1 ) and 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene ( 2 ) are shown. Tyrosol (RT = 8.93), 2,4-di- tert -butyl phenol (RT = 10.01), nerolidol (RT = 10.67), and farnesol (RT = 12.48) are endogenous compounds detected in all extracts including the empty vector control strain. Mass spectra of endogenous compounds are shown in Fig. S3. RT: retention time (min), IS: internal standard n -tetradecane.

heading.emphasis: 4.6. In vivo enzymatic assay and product isolation

subSection.paragraph:
The complete ORF of AabrBOS s and AabrSPS was transferred via pENTR/D-TOPO into a pYES-DEST52 (ThermoFisher Scientific) vector using Gateway LR Clonase II Enzyme Mix (ThermoFisher Scientific) to construct expression clones. Expression clones were introduced into
S . cerevisiae
strain EPY300. Yeast cells harboring the pYES2/CT empty vector (ThermoFisher Scientific) were used as a negative control. Transgenic yeast cells were cultured as described previously ( Muangphrom et al., 2018 ). Cells of the resulting cultures were then disrupted by sonication at room temperature for 30 min and extracted three times with EtOAc (for yeast expressing AabrBOS ) or EtOEt (for yeast expressing AabrSPS ). After drying the combined organic layer over anhydrous Na 2 SO 4 , the samples were concentrated under reduced pressure with a flow of nitrogen gas. Crude extracts were further purified by silica gel column chromatography and analyzed by GC-MS as described in 4.7 . The chemical structures of the purified compounds were analyzed with a Bruker AVANCE III HD 600 MHz NMR spectrometer (Bruker, Osaka , Japan ) using CDCl 3 as a solvent. Chemical shifts are reported as δ (ppm) relative to those of the internal standard tetramethylsilane ( δH = 0 ppm) or CDCl 3 ( δH = 7.24 ppm, δC = 77.0 ppm). The absolute configuration of the α- bisabolol product of AabrBOS1 was identified from its optical rotation using a JASCO P-1020 polarimeter (JASCO, Tokyo , Japan ) with a 50-mm microcell (1 mL) as compared with that of standard (-)-α- bisabolol. Endogenous compounds produced in yeast, tyrosol, di- tert -butyl phenol, nerolidol, and farnesol, were identified by comparison of their mass spectra with those available in the NIST mass spectral library (The NIST Mass Spectral Search Program for the NIST/EPA/NIH Mass Spectral Library version 2.2, 2014).

For sesquiterpenoid profiling of
A . abrotanum , GC-MS
analysis was performed using a 6890 A gas chromatograph (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA ) connected to a JMS-AM SUN200 mass spectrometer (JEOL, Tokyo , Japan ) and HP-5MS capillary column ( 30 m × 0.25 mm i.d., film thickness 0.25 μm; J&W Scientific, Santa Clara, CA, USA ) with a fused silica capillary tube ( 1 m × 0.25 mm i.d., GL-Sciences). The temperature program began at 60 ̊ C and increased at a rate of 3 ̊ C /min to 280 ̊ C where it was held for 6 min and 40 s.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 5. Biosynthetic mechanism of sesquiterpenoids catalyzed by all characterized sesquiterpene synthases from
Artemisia spp.
The biosynthesis of α- isocomene by MrTPS2 from
M . recutita ( Irmisch et al., 2012 )
is also included. The reaction mechanism begins with the ionization of farnesyl pyrophosphate (FPP). Enzymes responsible for the biosyntheses of amorpha-4,11-diene, 4-amorphen-11-ol, koidzumiol, (+)-α- bisabolol, ( E )-β- farnesene, germacrene A, and 8- epi -cedrol were previously reported as indicated in Fig. 3. Only major sesquiterpenoid products synthesized from each responsible sesquiterpene synthase are shown. Key compounds in this study, (+)-α- bisabolol ( 1 ) and 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene ( 2 ), are highlighted in bold. Presilphiperfolan-8-yl cation was previously proposed to be a common precursor of triquinane-type sesquiterpenoids including α- isocomene and 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene ( Pinedo et al., 2008 ; Wang and Tantillo, 2008 ).

subSection.paragraph: For the in vivo enzymatic assay, GC-MS analysis was performed using a 7890B gas chromatograph (Agilent Technologies) connected to a 5977 A MSD mass spectrometer (Agilent Technologies) and HP-5MS capillary column with a fused silica capillary tube of the same length and internal diameter as those described above. The temperature program was held at 100 ̊ C for 2 min and increased at a rate of 10 ̊ C /min to 280 ̊ C where it was held for 5 min.

In all analyses, the injection port temperature was set at 250 ̊ C . The carrier gas was He, and the flow rate was set to 0.7 ml/min. Split injection (1 μL) was conducted at a ratio of 1:10. The scanning speed of the mass spectrometer was two scans/s from m/z 40–350 at an electron voltage of 70 eV.
None.

We are grateful to the Ocean Exposition Commemorative Park Management Foundation ( Okinawa , Japan ) for providing
A. abrotanum
plants. We thank Dr. Kyoko Inoue ( Osaka University) for technical support with NMR analysis, Mr. Tsutomu Hosouchi and Ms. Sayaka Shinpo (Kazusa DNA Research Institute) for technical support with the Illumina sequencing. This work was supported by Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research on Innovative Areas, Nos. JP17H05442 and JP19H04657 to H.Seki.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2019.05.010.
